D2836AF8B1494464835F4E07A75A35A3.description: Students conduct cost-benefit analyses of historical and current events.

17966D94752045FAA3E132580520546E.description:
Students identify and interpret the multiple causes and effects of historical
 events.

E272722DE901495F8F7A10EA325ED209.description:
Students identify the human and physical characteristics of the places they are
 studying and explain how those features form the unique character of those
 places.

49B1BE37E8764624B8079A4D277DE42A.description:
Students summarize the key events of the era they are studying and explain
 the historical contexts of those events.

EB64AFECEC9449D689D7A9812CD46C1B.description:
Students distinguish fact from fiction by comparing documentary
 sources on historical figures and events with fictionalized characters
 and events.

EF97A2068A454A75B88421AEA8C95128.description:
Students pose relevant questions about events they encounter in
 historical documents, eyewitness accounts, oral histories, letters,
 diaries, artifacts, photographs, maps, artworks, and architecture.

DFFA30E940B443C2BD7C228330E2988E.description: Students differentiate between primary and secondary sources.

BA069E263DAE4AD2807DA77AA3731F47.description: Students judge the significance of the relative location of a place

328397AC26E6407E891C6803A0D0C97F.description:
Students use map and globe skills to determine the absolute locations of places
 and interpret information available through a map’s or globe’s legend, scale,
 and symbolic representations.

4D050B9F773C41E7A655202FEC8231E5.description:
Students explain how the present is connected to the past, identifying both
 similarities and differences between the two, and how some things change over
 time and some things stay the same.

1E8E8C4B514F4FF195660F63B90034F7.description:
Students correctly apply terms related to time, including past, present, future,
 decade, century, and generation.

042B009FA3834B649B17F28523BE195C.description:
Students place key events and people of the historical era they are studying in a
 chronological sequence and within a spatial context; they interpret time lines.

58060D4FB22D4E88B191F4446E05BC7B.description:
Examine the effect of Western Expansion and how territories became
part of the United States, including the significance of the Mexican-American War.

271C909D090F4ECF9AF633F8407826A1.description: Describe the experiences of settlers on the overland trails to the West.

D214CD1BA6A94100AE7C01641FB8C683.description:
Demonstrate knowledge of the explorations of the trans-Mississippi West
following the Louisiana Purchase.

CB30A63C59784C5AA1CD8EB03F5C281A.description:
Identify the states and territories that existed in 1850, and compare and
contrast their locations and major geographical features.

2B9641DCA308464890F677DB421E4ED1.description:
Illustrate the influx of immigrants from Europe between 1789 and l850
and compare their modes of transportation into the Ohio and Mississippi
Valleys and through the Cumberland Gap.

97F991F5D2664B68BE0968B0B2E94D7E.description:
Students trace the colonization, immigration, and settlement,
patterns of American people from 1789 to mid-l800’s, with
emphasis on the role of economic incentives, effects of the
physical and political geography, and transportation systems.

5487997F429E4E5C869A01FB9B39058D.description:
Know and explain the significance of the songs that express American
Ideals and how music contributes to cultural development.

9985819A5E994F299259213CD8C31BD4.description:
Demonstrate civic responsibility in group and individual actions, including
civic disposition such as civility, cooperation, respect, and responsible
participation.

CB2310A6308446ED944C254DB24DC625.description:
Examine ways by which citizens may effectively voice opinions, monitor
government, and bring about changes in government and the public agenda
including voting.

CD790FDCFD614B29BE03BB03B553E55E.description:
Discuss the meaning of the American creed that calls on citizens to
safeguard the liberty of individual Americans within a unified nation, to
respect the rule of law, and to preserve the Constitution.

2AF1555CB0784E0D892744096DAB4669.description:
Demonstrate how the Constitution is designed to secure our liberty by
both empowering and limiting central government and compare the powers
granted to citizens, Congress, the President, and the Supreme Court with
those reserved to the states.

B07A647A89CA4F21BD99262C36C50289.description:
Illustrate the fundamental principles of American constitutional democracy,
including how the government derives its power from the people and the
primacy of individual liberty.

B81F3D7D5B064B36B176CA277B0A632E.description:
Explain the significance of the new Constitution of 1787, including the
struggles over its ratification and the reasons for the addition of the Bill
of Rights.

DA810EFCF80F4496B2B4DBCC697BC85C.description:
List the shortcomings of the Articles of Confederation as set forth by its
critics.

696C1DB8D2C04429B26EDB4441C809F3.description:
Students describe the people and events associated with the development of the U.S. Constitution and analyze the
Constitution’s significance in the foundation of the American
republic.

6410F348A280454F82A517994BFC8FCE.description:
Compare and contrast the ideals set forth in the Declaration of
Independence and how it changed the way people viewed slavery.

797EBD034A8A4C4981B103DC9475C39C.description:
Demonstrate knowledge of the significance of land policies developed
under the Continental Congress

AA722984AC5841ECACED2815588243ED.description:
Understand the personal impact and economic hardships of the war on
families, problems of financing the war, wartime inflation, and laws
against hoarding goods and materials and profiteering.

A8F21052E2174DC8B0BF8FB5C6EA5839.description: Examine the different roles women played during the Revolution.

A99251AF25A5488B850F1E845732DAEA.description:
Describe the contributions of France and other nations and of individuals
to the outcome of the Revolution.

EF7CE086C06844F8858FA017D36D0729.description:
Identify and map the major military battles, campaigns, and turning
points of the Revolutionary War, the roles of the American and British
leaders, and the Indian leaders’ alliances on both sides.

26F185B4B75549BFAC8600D099AED349.description:
Students understand the course and consequences of the
American Revolution.

55369F9370AA41A4A94A000DE1AB0756.description:
Describe and compare the views, lives, and impact of key individuals
during this period.

258FE0296C9F48A4B14EE1855D71FC33.description:
Understand the significance of the relationship between people and
events associated with the drafting and signing of the Declaration of
Independence and the document’s significance, including the key political
concepts, the origins of those concepts, and its role in severing
ties with Great Britain.

061BFED98F7A4091B6BA53303D07DE38.description:
Understand how political, religious, and economic ideas and interests
brought about the Revolution.

6F13EDFAFAD6409AAFF59B6D8555022F.description: Students explain the causes of the American Revolution.

12DF9BC61D984A80AE9875A4A128D396.description:
Explain the significance of early democratic ideas and practices that
emerged during the colonial period, including representative assemblies
and town meetings.

786DAC5B01984982A32C6D88CC92B6CF.description:
Describe the introduction of slavery into America, and appraise the
responses of slave families to their condition, the ongoing struggle between proponents and opponents of slavery, and the gradual
institutionalization of slavery in the South.

884C8D6D5B5D4014B418651999A7A0AB.description:
Illustrate how the British colonial period created the basis for the
development of political self-government and a free-market economic system
and the differences between the British, Spanish and French colonial
systems.

F610E2AE86044B1CA8A229683777A4FC.description:
Describe the significance of religious influences on the earliest colonies
and the growth of religious toleration and free exercise of religion.

C27EC871E7874319A0E83786D1EC757A.description:
Identify the major individuals and groups responsible for the founding of
the various colonies and the reasons for their founding.

6D71362EB0514434BFF8D9E2EA3D8DCD.description:
Explain the influence of location and physical setting on the founding of
the original thirteen colonies and the American Indian nations inhabiting
these areas.

7EB2681CDDC64846ABD345DB883BA14B.description:
Students understand the political, religious, social, and
economic institutions that evolved in the colonial era.

974D228088B9423480AA160CFD93C2ED.description:
Evaluate the influence and achievements of significant leaders of the
time

C8A850DC039442EE99F0CED96A1920CF.description:
Appraise the role of broken treaties and massacres and the factors that
led to the Indian defeat, including the resistance of Indian nations to
encroachments and assimilation

DBD2F721ED8248EB9425333901CC8998.description: Examine the conflicts before the Revolutionary War.

0F9BA78941624626B86BB12C4EC13021.description:
Evaluate the cooperation that existed between the colonists and Indians
during the 1600s and 1700s.

3E143BB4E44F47F188E2CE108C0201BF.description:
Evaluate the competition among the English, French, Spanish, Dutch,
and Indian nations for control of North America.

244FF31DA4CF4969B098325450E31D55.description:
Students describe the cooperation and conflict that existed among
the American Indians and between the Indian nations and the new
settlers.

E9CEA75B16A24197A999394683B41724.description:
Locate on maps of North and South America land claimed by Spain,
France, England, Portugal, the Netherlands, Sweden, and Russia.

C411BC144ECA485BB2C17F75EBED07ED.description:
Trace the routes of the major land explorers of the United States, the
distances traveled by explorers, and the Atlantic trade routes that linked
Africa, the West Indies, the British colonies, and Europe.

1537BDCE07A8454D8B0EFB708B7694C4.description:
Compare the aims, obstacles, and accomplishments of the explorers,
sponsors, and leaders of key European expeditions and the reasons
Europeans chose to explore and colonize the world.

EB668AAAE03F42919B044B5C2630ACD4.description:
Explain the entrepreneurial characteristics of early explorers, Christopher
Columbus, Francisco Vasquez de Coronado, Hernando Magellan, and the
technological developments that made sea exploration by latitude and
longitude possible.

ADFB71127AE2423A8F57BB28E4043A77.description:
Students trace the routes of early explorers and describe the
early explorations of the Americas.

179330CE184244D0951BC245AE7EF748.description: Explain Pre-Columbian varied economics and systems of government.

71A4014A3EBC4BC19FCD68EBE258EEE3.description: Recognize Pre-Columbian varied customs and folklore traditions

CBB8C940A1754A26BA4591457F3C9E87.description:
Compare and contrast how geography and climate influenced the way
various nations lived and adjusted to the natural environment, including
locations of villages, the distinct structures that they built, and how they
obtained food, clothing, tools, and utensils.

B0277B918E204F96BE93E7BC46B9D2F0.description:
Students describe the major pre-Columbian settlement(s)
of cliff dwellers and pueblo people of the desert Southwest, the
American Indians of the Pacific Northwest, the nomadic
nations of the Great Plains, and the woodland peoples
east of the Mississippi River
